data.text: requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0
Contents
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0

This document is to provide a standard operating procedure for patients with COVID-19 and requiring oxygen therapy, a safe transfer home with clinical support provided by H@H and to aid weaning from oxygen therapy and recovery for COVID-19. It has been produced in line with NHS England and NHS Improvement requirement to deliver COVID virtual wards as set out in https://www.england.nhs.uk/coronavirus/publication/covid-virtual-ward/
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on the safe procedure for patients receiving virtual care from H@H or community providers jointly with the MSEFT respiratory services.
Discharge of patients with COVID Oximetry at home without oxygen will be managed through SDEC and not included in this SOP.

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust

data.text: Role & Responsibilities of committees within the Trust

The Quality and Patient Safety Committee (SUHFT) are responsible for ensuring the trust is providing a high quality service, monitor and review the quality of services and be responsible to significant patient safety risks.

The Quality and Patient Safety Committee (MEHT) are responsible for ensuring the trust is providing a high quality service, monitor and review the quality of services and be responsible to significant patient safety risks.
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
Page  of
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0

The Risk and Compliance Committee (BTUH) are responsible for ensuring the trust is providing a high quality service, monitor and review the quality of services and be responsible to significant patient safety risks.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Site Medical Director:

Each Site Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Site Director of Nursing:

Each Site Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Site Director of Operations:
Each site Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that the systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Director of Operations for Care Group 4:

The Director of Operations for Care Group 4 is responsible for ensuring that the systems and processes are disseminated appropriately and compliance is adhered to in conjunction with the site Directors of Operations.
Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Directorates/Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Directorate/Divisional General Managers/Associate Directors:

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Page  of
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0

Directorate/Divisional Heads of Nursing and Quality (HoNQ): The HoNQs are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.

Head of Integrated Care: The Head of Integrated care is responsible for ensuring for that monitoring and audit of the service are undertaken and that this document is fully implemented at departmental level

Hospital@Home Virtual Ward Managers: H@H Ward Mangers are responsible for implementing this document in the Virtual Ward environment and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Operational Lead and Head of Integrated Care

Hospital@Home Operational Lead for the service: H@H Operational Lead is responsible for ensuring that all staff within the Hospital at Home service comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will ensure that all necessary training is provided and competencies kept current.
Medical Staff: The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
Nursing Staff:

The nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the virtual ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.

The H@H service has capacity to provide care for  patients from each of the MSEFT hospital sites. These patients will be identified on each site's TeleTracking ‘Hospital at Home virtual ward'. Depending on capacity service will be delivered flexibly in collaboration with the site's local community respiratory team.
This service will accept the following cohort of patients:
The patient is an inpatient, with a diagnosis of Covid-19 (may or may not have co- morbidities)
Is receiving (and is stable) on 1-8 litres of Oxygen therapy and is identified as appropriate for this pathway by a Respiratory Consultant or Respiratory Clinical
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0
Nurse specialist. Community teams can only support patients requiring a maximum of 4 litres.
The patient consents and is able to demonstrate effective usage of a pulse oximeter or a carer/family member can support them to do this
The patient is able to use Tele medicine technology/system
Referral Monday – Friday

Patients who are  days post confirmed COVID will be identified by the respiratory team, who will assess the suitability for transfer into H@H. If the patient is suitable they will be referred by telephone to the H@H team by the respiratory clinical nurse specialist or consultant. During this assessment made by the respiratory nurse, the patient will be informed of the involvement of H@H and the use of remote monitoring and gain consent for remote monitoring and/or attend anywhere system.

The patient will also be informed of how often they should be recording their oxygen saturation levels once they are home, and how to use the oxygen concentrator and titrate their oxygen once home under clinical guidance. The H@H team must have clear instruction of care including target saturations, oxygen prescriptions and evidence of consent.
Process Monday - Friday

H@H will conduct a telephone assessment with the transferring ward, and confirm acceptance of patient with the Respiratory CNS or responsible consultant, who will then arrange home oxygen delivery via BOC to be in situ in time for patients transfer home (4 hour O2 delivery for same day transfers), and ensure a copy of their care plan and assessments are sent to H@H. The patient must not leave hospital without acceptance from H@H.

H@H will contact Kraydel to inform them of the patient and arrange installation of all required devices for remote monitoring, this will be completed within 24 hours of referral. In the event Kraydel are unable to install required equipment in time for a patients transfer, H@H will use the Attend Anywhere system to conduct remote monitoring until Kraydel are able to install equipment. In the event neither of these systems are available contact will be made any telephone and a home visit.
Weekend referrals

Over the weekend the H@H office is not manned and therefore for referrals over the weekend should be made as shown below. Referrals should only be made if H@H have capacity to accept patients, the available capacity will be shared by email from H@H to Clinical site teams and the respiratory CNS's on each site on a Friday at 4pm.
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0

H@H will contact the patient once they have arrived home and arrange a home visit within 24hours of transfer from hospital. During this visit the nurse will ensure the patient is capable of using the monitoring equipment and they will give the patient information leaflets including key contact numbers to explain their on-going care.

The patient will have an allocated time slot each day for a video consultation with H@H to discuss their care, issues and observations, the patient will be informed of this time slot on the first home visit.
Where a patient is transferred over a weekend the H@H team will advise them of their virtual consultation time on their first contact with H@H.

H@H will regularly check data from either the remote monitoring portal or the pulse oximeter supplied to the patient on transfer. The patient will record their observations as set out in their care plan.

H@H through the consultation will provide advice and support based on these readings to the patients in regards to titrating oxygen to meet their needs. This can be given via video conferencing or if required H@H can arrange a home visit.

An MDT will be held at least 2 times weekly with the respiratory team therapies, H@H and the community teams, to discuss each patient, their current condition and review and revise care plans should it be required. During this MDT the discharge plan for each patient should be discussed and decided to ensure early referral into community services, ready for when the patient is medically optimised to be discharged.
A Pando App group will be available for each site and will include all members of the hospital MDT to provide and safe communication line and to be able to share patient information quickly.
All services involved in the patient care should use System 1 to document all interventions
A patient information leaflet will be supplied on transfer.
Covid virtual ward - transfer of covid positive patients home under the care of hospital @ home (H@H),
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0
Target Oxygen saturation levels for COVID Positive patients will be set in the care plan.
Patients with known COPD and/or type 2 respiratory failure - 88%-92%
Patients with no underlying respiratory conditions- 90%-94.

In the event a patient become unwell or their observations are deteriorating, H@H should arrange an urgent Video consultation with the patient, and ensure oxygen titration is being done correctly in liaison with the Respiratory team.

If the patient is visibly unwell but stable, H@H will arrange an urgent home visit and liaise with the Respiratory Nurse Specialist to discuss treatment plan, and titration of oxygen. If required, and support with Blood Gases is needed please contact community respiratory team who may be able to assist with this.
Following assessment if the patient needs to return to hospital contact the respiratory Nurse specialist who will liaise with the consultant to arrange transfer back into the hospital.

If a patient becomes unwell and requires urgent review at the weekend, H@H should contact the respiratory consultant on call via hospital switchboard. For new patients transferred into the service at a weekend and whose health declines, the Community Nurse will contact the respiratory consultant on call via hospital switchboard.
In the event of a medical emergency call 999 for urgent assistance.
Expected discharge date should be agreed on transfer into H@H with the respiratory team, and reviewed at every MDT meeting.
Patients will be discharged from H@H in two ways:

Once it is decided the patient is ready to be discharged from H@H and require input from the community Respiratory team, they should be referred to the community respiratory team via SYSTM ONE using the allocated template (see appendix And a supporting telephone call.

If the patient no longer requires oxygen the patient will be discharged from H@H and followed up by the Acute respiratory team who will be informed of discharge via Systm One and verbally in MDT meeting.
Patients requiring up to 4litres of oxygen can be discharged to community services to enable H@H service to support higher acuity patients
Page  of
requiring oxygen therapy and pulse oximetry / MSESOP-21005/ 1.0
On discharge from H@H service Kraydel equipment must be collected from the patient's house and returned to H@H office, this will be arranged by H@H staff.
Once equipment has been collected it must be cleaned as per infection control guidelines and returned to MEMs.
Mandatory resus training for all nursing staff
Clinical incident reporting training for all staff
Anaphylaxis training for all nursing staff
Oxygen saturations monitoring.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Control Centre and Integrated Care Divisional Governance and Performance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the Control Centre and Integrated Care Divisional Governance and Performance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 8)

Appendix 3: Using the pulse oximeter
PLEASE WASH HANDS THOROUGHLY BEFORE USE AND REMOVE NAIL VARNISH FROM ONE FINGER IF NECESSARY.
Turn the device on using the  button on the display screen not all devices have this button and turn on automatically.

data.url: MSESOP-21005 Covid virtual ward at home requiring oxygen therapy and oximetry 1.0.003.png

data.text: Squeeze the device under the display area between your thumb and forefinger on both the top and bottom of the device to open pulse oximeter. Place index or middle finger inside the pulse oximeter, the digital display needs to be visible to you. If the display does not light up it may be that the batteries need to be replaced then turn the device over, slide the battery cover off and replace batteries (see diagram)
A green light will show when a good connection has been made and two numbers will also be visible, if the light remains red then remove the device and place it back on the finger.

The device will show both your oxygen levels (Sp02) which should be between 90 – 100 and your heart rate (PR) which should be between 60 - 100, these numbers can vary sometimes from these perimeters and can fluctuate. Please record both numbers as we will be asking you for them.
Remove device from finger and return the Sats Probe into the bag that the probe originally arrived in.
Device Display
